titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Constance Applebee (1873-1981) was a British athlete and educator who introduced and promoted the sport of women's field hockey in the United States. Despite a frail childhood, she graduated from London's British College of Physical Education. Beginning in 1904 and continuing for 25 years, Applebee served as director of outdoor sports at Bryn Mawr. In 1922 she helped found the United States Field Hockey Association, and the following year created a field hockey camp in Mount Pocono, Pennsylvania. For 10 years, Applebee was the editor and publisher of Sportswoman, a magazine for women athletes.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the personal and professional papers of Constance Applebee. Included are programs and scrapbooks of the United States Field Hockey Association (USFHA) and the International Federation of Women's Hockey (IFWHA); copies of the Sportswoman and the Eagle; correspondence, clippings, and memorabilia about Applebee's role in women's field hockey; and documents relating to Applebee's war relief work. In addition there are papers and memorabilia related to Applebee's long association with Bryn Mawr College, including sketches of May Day costumes and class books. The collection also includes books on sports, health, and other topics, as well as a small series of correspondence, birthday greetings, and materials collected by H.K. Welsh and H.W. Smith for their book on Applebee.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: A paper finding aid is available in the repository.
